pageContext.desc: Civil War officer with the 2nd Iowa Infantry and commander of the 47th Colored Infantry Regiment.
pageContext.category: Diaries; American Civil War (1861-1865); Family papers

pages.transcription: Diary 1866

H. Scofield of Washington Iowa
Col 47th Regt NSC[?] [unclear]
[unclear] $14.32 ch 13/61 [unclear] 
[?] 3/61 Pa $
Jun 31/63
page from an almanac?--image

1866
Baton Rouge, LA Monday, January 1.
Rained all day most of the time very hard - Purchased this diary in the morning for $1.75 - Was at the office in the forenoon - Afternoon spent in my tent cleaning up the Burnside carbines which I have obtained from the Pro Main Office. We fired oysters at a restaurant with Dr. unclear Summer Friday next fixed for the Muster out of our Reg't-- The Mayor invited me over to tea but I had already supped.
unclear 51 xx

1866.

Tuesday, January 2.
Baton Rouge La
Cleared off this morning + the mud dried during the day - To night it is clear + cold - The river has risen 20 inches I am told + some of the guns at the landing near under water.
- Have not spent much time at the office - Surgeon Mcunclear ordered in anest. by unclear Canby - no news - Have spent the evening with the unclear - Mr. Elom playing cards + - Saw the dress parade of the 65th tonight - level unclear complained that his rifle had no wood + -Spent some time cleaning my carbines

Wednesday, January 3, 1866
Baton Rouge, LA
Clear a cold but not unpleasant. Did not sleep quite unclear last night. The 55th colored Rgt left in the night. Spent the forenoon is the office doing business + reading the papers. After dinner went to the arsenal purchased cartridges + for my carbines. Bought 200 cartridges at the rate of about $31.00 per thousand. All of unclear the unclear officer was very kind. Since supper had been sitting in my bed + thinking what I shall say to the Regt tomorrow. There is very little news. I retire now at 10:15 o'clock-- a fine week fire is burning + the sheets are turned down invitingly

1866 Thursday January 4th
Baton Rouge La
Spent the forenoon in the office doing business - left Ward all quartered by the Martial
At 2 PM made a speech to the Regiment of about an hour + a half advising them as to their future life. The Major Mr [Elon] was present + remarked to me that a man must be very blind not to see the future change in relations of the Blacks to the Whites.
The 48th Regt mustered out to day - Paymaster has come Called + spent the evening with the Mayor Mr. [Elam] in company with [Sumner] He gave an account of a Lieut Todd of the {unclear] how he seduced (probably) one of the ladies of the 1st circles

1866 Friday January 5
Baton Rouge La
At about 10.30 am was with the Regt mustered out of the service by Lieut M L Mitchell + Lieut 1st [unclear] mustering officer Made the necessary affidavits + received my papers which will I hope enable me to get my pay - Part of the 46th Regt came to day - Dined with Mr [Elom] in company with the Adjt and the Doctor - Clear cool fine day - 9:30 PM sit in my tent while some colored men in Adjt's tent are playing the violin and [unclear] just played [unclear]
while I stood by the chimney looking in – Nothing new to day – I fear we will not be paid tomorrow not until Sunday

1866 Saturday January 6
Pleasant but cool today. Begin to feel that my story is short here. Bought and commenced reading "Our Mutual Friend" (Dickens). Sat in my tent the greater part of the day. Will be paid I think tomorrow spoke to the [unclear] after [unclear]
Supped again with the [unclear] played cards + conversed after supper until about 10 PM when I retire.

1866 Sunday January 7
Commenced making arrangements to leave. Made up my papers taking an oath before the Major [Elam] + was paid with the Regiment. 1180 miles were all that was allowed. Have not sold my horse + fear shall be detained. Went to a boarding house in the city [Brother Dr unclear Sumner ] to go down the river in the
Some of the soldiers as I had feared had trouble + some were robbed

1866 Monday January 8
Baton Rouge La
Genl Danblorre [antebellum] of the 461st came today
- Beautiful day
Been all day trying to sell my horse and been foiled in every attempt Never was so much annoyed in any undertaking – The Major deceived me once or twice when I had relied upon him to take it – Tonight am as mad as a wet hen for I will not be able to leave tomorrow morning as I had fondly expected – Must stay now amother day
Exchanged my small bills a $1000.00 bill at the bank here
Walked around the town tonight looking for the soldier who talked of taking the horse

1866 Tuesday January 9
Did not sleep well last night – My trouble and perplexity in the sale of my horse put me in a fever + I spent an hour or two in determining what to do in the morning Sold the horse to a Mr Blessing for about $40.00 less than he should have been sold for but I was determined to end the matter + sold him – Went aboard the [OhiBranch] in the morning + have spent the day aboard. Tomorrow shall be in Vicksburg + – – – – – The [bank?] has some trouble with the men which I settled without trouble This is a great boat to travel on Almost a year since we went down the river on this boat under very different circumstances

1866 Wednesday January 10
Spent the day on the steamboat working and [trifling?] – Arrived at Vicksburg about 5 ON + went to the Wash. hotel – Met Col Young + Dr Davis – [Young Morarty?] + I spent
a pleasant evening + called early upon my old friend _____ + spent the night
There are those who are glad to me – This seems to be quite a lively place just now though it looks the same old place – Capt Banks + [Marsha?] + Picket + wife stop with me at the hotel – The day has been cold with indications of a coming storm

_ _ b   g XX

1866 Thursday January 11
Slept away from the hotel last night returning in time for a late breakfast – Windy + an unpleasant day Saw Genl Osterhuisn Genl [Amish] Cols Lieb Compton Young + [unclear] Compton [unclear] at night + spent a pleasant hour
Sat for my picture
At night called upon my friend – + remained until a late hour + then returned to the hotel where there was so much noise that sleep was difficult though to me not impossible Vicksburg is much theplace it was – Genl Osterhuis is a Dutchman but a pleasant one
Dined with friend Barber + lady

1866 Friday January 12
Vicksburg Miss
Called upon my friend in the morning + bid goodbye _ _ _ _ Spent the day at the hotel waiting for a boat + getting none – Very dull and tiresome. Met with Major [McKeemer?] of the 11th [cav] Reg [unclear] almost a sh[ .... ]ting aff[ray] at the hotel
The Mississippi arrives fresh before dark + [nepet] off about 8 o clock. Dr Norton [unclear] came up on the boat – This has been a warm pleasant day – I now sit writing this in the cabin of the steamer – Am a little perplexed in mind as to whether I ought or ought not to take some interest in cotton planting this year – Before coming aboard drank a bottle of wine with Genl Gilchrist Davi Gonfpint] Col Risden

1866 Saturday January 13
On Steamer Mississippi at or about Columbia Ark 9 PM –
Did not run but little last night + have not made fast progress today – Dr Horton + the man from the {Yazoo?] got off at [unlear] – Was introduced + had some conversation with Mr [unclear] of Lake Providence – Slept some after dinner + feel the worse for it – [unclear] today in the "Mutual Friend" Book [unclear]

1866 Sunday January 14
Miss River
– Cloudy foggy rainy + cold
– Did not run far last night on account of the fog. Genl Meeting  + the Episcopal service in the morning and at night by the Rev Shepherd of Montgomery Ala – Had some conversation with him + with a Presbyterian minister aboard – Read a good deal today
Am getting tired of travelling + shall be glad when home again –
All quiet today and no news
Did not rest well last night – Took a nap to day

1866 Monday January 15
Rained in the morning cleared off pleasant with some wind blowing
– Reached Memphis early in the morning – Did not leave the boat – Read the papers [unclear]here – Read a good deal in Our Mutual Friend Am now getting well [unclear] the matter indicates it – Sit up until about midnight reading – This is very good boat [unclear] though there seems a lack of attention at the table on the part of the waiters [Tried unclear] aboard. [unclear] from Ark

1866 Tuesday January 16
Miss River [and unclear]
Clear + cold all day though pleasant aboard – Passed New Madrid + the other places of interest on the river + shall be in {unclear] (probably) about dark – {Find today in] in running in the [unclear] in considerable quantities – A good feeling seems to prevail aboard + the trip is a pleasant one though I shall feel delighted when at home once more
Took sleeping car + a bunk with Rev. Shepherd the Episcopal clergyman from Mont Ala. On the trip became acquainted with Rev. McCullough of near Austin Texas 
who told me of my friend Baldwin of Indianola [?]

1866
Wednesday, January 17.
On the train. Leave Cairo at 2 AM run 11 miles &  hook ? check? down &  lay ? until morning --  burning ? in the morning on the part of the passengers. Several cars off the track with considerable of a smash up & a poor prospect ahead.
Get off about 2 PM & move slowly forward with nothing to eat except what is profered up at the stores at the stations. A good deal of grumbling. At night take sleeping car + retire with a prospect of a fair nights rest.

1866
Thursday, January 18.
On the cars. Ill. Central RR  Arrived at Chicago about noon & went to the Tremont ? house + ate a hearty dinner - A better hotel than when I was here before in 1856  After dinner with Capts Banks & Nershe?]] went to clothing store + bought our clothing - I bought two complete suits & an overcoat amounting to $145.00  Bought a hat for $4.50 Gloves $2.00  
A Mr Washburn whom I knew at Washington come in and sat an hour - 
Went to the Depot at 11 PM & take the cars for Washington at 12 Midnight. Take a sleeping car. Met at the Depot Capt. Devereaux ?  & men of my Reg't

1866 
Friday, January 19.
On the cars.
Left Chicago at midnight. Arrive at Davenport at about 9 AM. At Washington about 2 PM. Rested very well in the sleeping car. Home again with kind friends to greet me. 
Find brother William here but Sherman away at unclear City. Holden too is away at Muscatine. 
Find one of my rooms rented & the other very dirty. Eat a very hearty supper at Mrs. Axbells & sleep there. The office being so very dirty. Am glad enough to be home again.

1866 
Saturday, January 20.
Washington Iowa.
Went to work in the morning shifting and arranging matters in my room. Sent up to the house + don't know how many pairs of old pants +c. Mak[e] a very decided change for the better though much yet remains to be done. Saw a good many of my old friends in the town + from the country. At night called upon Mrs. Chilcote & Mrs. Owen. Return early. Holden come back to day & it seems like old times to meet so many of them I have before known so familiarly.

1866 
Sunday, January 21.
Washington Iowa.
Did not rest very well last night. Slept in the office again last night. 
Went to the ME Church & heard the minister preach a very good sermon. Spent the most of the day in the office. Sherman come back just at night having had a cold ride from Iowa ? City. The weather is quite cold + I have a bad cold. Took a bath in very cold water in the morning + thought I would perish.

1866 
Monday, January 22.
Washington, Iowa.
Snowed all day & is cold & unpleasant. Have spent the day unclear-ing ? dealing w? my private matters & find I have between four & five thousand dollars worth of notes. Willam Sherman is ? go? to a party at Crabbs while I call upon Mrs. Higgins & spend a pleasant evening. 
Ten PM sit in the office having just returned. William Sherman still away. Got our office clock back to day & I got my little diamond ring repaired at Sheldons.

1866 
Tuesday, January 23.
Washington Iowa.
Snowed all last night & into the day. Wind has driven the snow some. Made a few visits around the square. 
Received an invitation to Mrs. Owens to supper & went at 1/2 past 6. following underlined in red Met there a Miss Wilson, a teacher & an accomplished lady. end underlining Spent the evening pleasantly & then accompanied her home (to Mr. Jo Lewis). Have done nothing to day. Spent the day very idly & am ashamed of myself. Must get rid of my idle habits. 
Holden left to day for Des Moins. Am sorry he is gone.

1866 
Wednesday, January 24.
Washington, Iowa
Cold but not unpleasant. Did little or nothing to day. Engaged in a controversy with Mr. Jenkins &c. on political matters. Went around the square making calls where I was acquainted. At night called upon Dr. McRae & family with Sherman. Saw Squire Wilson & family there. Have made propositions for a settlement & hope soon to make one with the firm.

1866 Thursday, January 25.
Washington Iowa
A very pleasant day for a winter day in Iowa. Worked all day in the books preparatory to effecting a settlement as I hope of the firm accounts. A note amountin to $57.00 of Croth ? was paid & the mortgage security cancelled.
The members of the firm met at night & talked our business affairs over but did not arrive at a settlement. Sat up until midnight with Mr. Jenkins William & Sherman in conversation in which business was very little discussed.

1866 
Friday, January 26.
Washington Iowa
Snowed in the morning but cleared off warm & moderately pleasant soon after. To night it is cloudy with some prospects of a rain storm. Have accomplished literally nothing to day in the matter of the settlement for which I feel so anxious. Wrote to the Treasurer of unclear to ascertain the amount of my taxes for the year. Had quite a long talk with Col. Norwood ? Capt. Easton ? & the ex sheriff called to see me. Made a visit with my bro. & Sherman when Mr. underlined in red Patterson & family taking the ? there. Have just returned from making a visit to the house.

1866 
Saturday, January 27.
Washington Iowa
Has been damp & snowing some during the day. Rail road meeting at the bank unclear at 1 PM. Was present. Have not done much toward a settlement of the firm affairs & Sherman still working at the Books. 
Went calling at night, found underlined in red Miss Wilson not at home. Miss Mattie Dawes ditto. Finally went to Dr. Parkers & spent a very pleasant evening listening to music from the girls &c. Have just written a letter to Damien ? enclosing a photograph for Miss Parmalee.

1866 
Sunday January 28.
Washington Iowa
Pleasant winter day, has snowed a good deal. Went to hear Rev. Shearer preach in the morning at the courthouse. Had Huntley for dinner at Mrs. Actells.
Sherman has worked at the books a good deal during the day & night. At night went to hear Rev. Wagoner at the Congregational church. Had a bath in the morning.
Retired at midnight. To day burned up my old will, made before entering the service & (amended) after the battle of Shiloh when I was at home in the spring of 1862.

1866 
Monday, January 29.
Washington Iowa
A mild pleasant day. Snow melted fast & the sleighing is to night almost gone. I have worked hard all day & to night do not retire until one in the morning, feet cold & am feeling badly. A lecture to night at the Congregational church by the Rev. Malone ?. I sent an invitation to a lady (Miss W) red line in margin to escort her to the lecture but she was engaged teaching & I did not go.

1866 
Tuesday, January 30.
Fine winter day. Thawed the snow considerably. Twombly? came back to day & with him, per invitation we took supper at Dr Parkers. Attended the festival at the ME Church & spent a smal sum. Escorted Miss W-- home & returned to the office at midnight. Met a good many friends at the church & spent a pleasant evening. Formed some acquaintances among Miss W's acquaintances, of a Miss Brown from San Francisco Colo.

1866 
Wednesday, January 31.
Finally succeeded in settling up the firm of which I was once a member, buying out both Patterson & Jenkins. Geo. ? Jenkins the accts of the firm [[?? ist] Geo. Reiston & Smith Andrews & Gene Pattison, a few old notes & $275.00 in money. Contracts were executed &c. deed of the lot & building made to me. I feel very well over the result. Worked hard all the day at the matter. Played ? with buyer &c. at night for a while.

1866
Thursday February 1
Have been very busy all day clearing up the safe and aproved? the? counter?. Sherman and I worked very hard and are not all done yet even then.  There is a weeks work before the the thing is put in final condition.  Have been at work at the account of unclear all the evening. It is now 12 midnight and I will retire soon. All else have gone. Read a letter from Darius? who got through from Baton Rouge safe.

1866
Friday February 2
Cold unclear unpleasant  Been as usual very busy in the office reunclearing the books and setting up the accounts so far as it could be done.  
paragraph marked through
[[At night called 
Sherman at Mr
& spent the evening 
that I
]] 
At night called upon Miss Wilson spent the evening very pleasantly. Have accomplished very little to day  Received a letter from Daniels?

1866
Saturday February 3
Cold and very unpleasant.  Worked in the office as usual and accomplished but little.
At night went to unclear Mr. Aurgers?with Sherman & spent the evening very pleasantly
Nothing new to-day. Everything exceedingly dull with little prospects for improvements
Patterson? went to Sigourney. He has something in his head dont? tell me what

Clear cold day.
Took a bath in the morning and then went unclear church and heard Dr Wilson preach. Wrote a long letter to __________. Read over some of my old letters.  Unclear up my old stove pipe hat.  At unclear went with Sherman to the Methodist Church.  Had some unclear several words stopped at the house and unclear staid? until the present 10 o clock and am now about to retire.

1866
Monday, February 5
Cold blustering day
A little more mild tonight
- Now just returned from underlined in red calling upon Mrs Nickershon 
- Found there Mrs Crabb and young Dr (Al) Rodman - Gone? by Shillings + took a glass of beer - Now been busy all day again in the office writing? + filing among? the letters - Feel very well pleased as this examination has resulted in unclearing a sum of about ten? hundred dollars in my favor. Brought up from the bank? house an old desk for my papers. Did not mail my letter to day as I should have done Things look decidedly improved? in the office.

1866
Tuesday, February 6.
Washington Iowa
A cold but not otherwise unpleasant day
= Busy in the office + paying taxes - Paid tax for 1865 + on the building for 1864 which Sherman wanted? to settle. The interest + all amounting to about $60.00. Total amt of tax paid by me $107.40
At night called at Mrs Allens + spent with the girls + Mrs Allen a pleasant evening. The family? on about leaving - Everything is dull in town thought the streets are full of people from the country

1866
Wednesday February 7
Cold day. Mrs [Axtiel?} is moving today. Sherman and I dined at Mr. [Bates?} and at night per invitation I took supper & spent the evening at [Col unclear]s house with Dr [Ahil} & lady Mr  [Green} & lady Charlie Wilson & lady Dr. [unclear] & lady & a Miss [unclear]
Spent a very pleasant evening & returning at 10 o'clock find the office deserted
Worked during the day at the accounts chiefly at the account of {GM Peliste] Mr Mc[Jenkin] returned today from Des Moins

1866
Thursday, February 8
Moderately pleasant day--Patterson returned from Sigoreney--Jo Lewis came in the morning.  MC Junkins? called in in the morning.  Spent the day working at the books. Sherman and Patterson now worked some to close up their matters though without success as yet.  Have accomplished but little to day the settling of the books is like to be a long troublesome job. Grill? Peters books + proceed to day in moving  hands for collection.
Went to meals to day at the [house formerly occupied by Ayan? + Mrs. Axtell moved in yesterday

1866
Friday, February 9
Thawed rapidly today. Some indications of a rain. Have not done so much to day as usual--Patterson has been at work at the books nearly all day + he + Sherman have at length are to an amazment for the settling up of their accounts.  Rheinart? is to be sent for to aid in the matter.  Patterson was out of the firm + to morrow we open new books for the firm of ___ ____  ____ ____ (not yet named)
Wrote to Darius.  Wrote to  Nolden?for a Notary commission.  At night called upon Miss Wilson.  At 10 PM + just back + propose soon to retire

1866
Saturday February 10
Washington Iowa
- Moderately pleasnt
Bought a knife at Dr. Parkers {?] $2.00 + a day book for the newfirm. Christened Scofield  + Sherman. Patterson Sherman close up their partnership to day.
At night called upon Mrs Chilcote had a very pleasant Mrs Chilcote + later in evening with the Doctor who returned from church - Mrs. Chilcote come home from church to visit with me though I was not advised of the fact until afterwards  - She had a matter of which she was anxious to speak -

1866
Sunday February 10
Clear but cold day
Did not go to church but spent the greater part of the day in copying the account of Patterson Scofield from the books of Patterson Sherman - Find a balance in my favor of about $800.00 for which I am very thanksful - Took a good bath + changed my clothes
- At night went to the Methodist church with William - Have just returned + am sitting at one end of the long table while Sherman is reading a little + Wm is working
A negro preacher from [Oskalinda?] took up a collection today for a church for the colored people there

1866
Monday February 12
Cold day - Afternoon commenced snowing
- Been in the office all day but have done nothing worth mentioning
- Sherman Patterson have finally arranged their matters. Holden come home from Des Moins - Spent the [morning?] at home for the first time for along a long time - Patterson bought the Thompson place

1866
Tuesday February 13
Cold stormy day - Snowed a good deal + at night is still snowing at a great rate - Have worked some but have not accomplished much
- Holden come up at night + we played [eucher?] [formia] Jack + other games
- Mc[justin] called up also in the early part of the evening + suggested that I ought to con[sent the a con for dst Jusope]
- Nothing new

1866
Wednesday February 14
The wind has blown apace the entire day + the snow which fell yesterday is tonight in heaps. It has been very cold. Had but two meals to day because to stormy to go [further?] - I have read some + made an examination of the Record of Deeds in the matter of [mine spanish Horworth] etc. - Sherman + Wm both went to see their ducks to night leaving me alone in the office. No train or mail through the day - Have felt lonely and had the blues all day - Sometines think of Dixie and wish myself back again

1866
Thursday February 15
Nothing new worth mentioning - Still feel lonely + blue + wish myself where the birds were singing - Wonder if anyone there would be glad to see me there! Have not heard from any of my friends there [unclear] come home Stranger!

1866
Friday February 16
Not so cold but still very cold - Began suit today against [Boris} + will sue John [unclear]  + perhaps others for  [unclear] Danson for taking [unclear]
from the college lot last fall some time
Have spent considerable time in studying the case - Sold y coupons today for about twelve dollars
Wrote to Capt Banks in the morning [unclear] enclosed him a [unclear]
No Eastern mail to day
Have eaten to much + do not feel quite well to night - Must eat less

1866
Saturday, February 17
A warm pleasant day compared with those preceding. Spent the day in the office as usual reading + studying the case of D[[unclear}} Boris.  Collective same authorities.  Sherman went to see his sheep up near Narris?burg.  At night went to see Miss W + staid until after 10 oclock.  Nothing new. Read a letter from Dr. Fletcher? chosing or closing? his photographer. Wrote him endorsing mine.  Bought some notes of Bill Thompson $200 unclear.

1866.
Sunday, February 18
Pleasant day. Rose at the usual hour. Breakfasted, Bathed + went to church at the Q V P's  + heard New ??.  At night went to M E Church + heard Rev. Miller preach a very good sermon.  Called at Mrs. Axtells after church + sat an hour.  Sherman returned from Harrisburg to-day.  Read some in my copy of Burris?.  Counseled a jury? fallen? in a louder? case in the morning + charged him three dollars (all at the door?)

1866. Thursday, March 22.
Weather wild + stormy
Rains this afternoon
No one not done so much to day as usual.
small flower?--image

pageContext.title: Hiram Scofield diary, 1866
